details.title: A multiple objective framework for planning accelerated life tests

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Ind. & Syst. Eng., Nat. Univ. of Singapore, Singapore

p: Loon-Ching Tang obtained his B.Eng. (1st class honors) in Mechanical Engineering, M.Eng. in Industrial Engineering, both from the National University of Singapore; and M.Sc. and Ph.D. degrees from Cornell University in the field of Operations Research, with minors in Statistics, and Civil Engineering. He has published widely in more than 20 international journals, including IEEE Transactions on Reliability, Journal of Quality Technology, IIE Transactions, Naval Research Logistics, and Queueing Systems, of which two awards for making outstanding contribution to the literature and body of knowledge; and a best technical paper award have been given. His primary research interest is in operations research techniques, with applications to quality and reliability problems; in particular, those related to accelerated testing.

authors.name: Loon-Ching Tang

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Ind. & Syst. Eng., Nat. Univ. of Singapore, Singapore

p: Kai Xu obtained his B.Eng. and Ph.D. degrees in Mechanical and Power Engineering, both from Huazhong University of Science and Technology, China. He has published articles in several international journals, including IIE, Journal of Quality Technology, Reliability Engineering and System Safety,IEEE Transactions on Electronic Packaging Manufacturing, SAE Transaction, and Applied Soft Computing, among others. His research interests are in process improvement through Response Surface Methodology, applications of Fuzzy Logic and Neural Networks in quality and reliability engineering. He is currently working for GE (China) research center in the field of six sigma and statistical quality and reliability engineering.

authors.name: Kai Xu

details.abstract: We consider a framework with two conflicting objectives in the planning of ALT; i.e., meeting a desired level of statistical precision for an estimate of interest, and meeting a cost target for conducting the test. This can easily be generalized to multiple objectives with, say, precision targets for various estimates, stress limits constraint, sample size constraint, etc. In the absence of actual cost, the cost of conducting the test is related to the total test time at different stress levels, and the total sample size needed for the test. The framework is applied to planning of constant stress ALT, in which the logarithm of the lifetime follows the extreme value distribution. The proposed framework consistently leads to more cost-effective test plans without compromising the precision of the estimate, and is equally robust to misspecification of initial estimates, compared with other test plans presented in the literature.

references.title: Best compromise test plans for weibull distributions with different censoring times

context.text: Some authors have considered test plans under some implicit cost constraints through the use of different censoring times at different levels of stresses [8], [9], expected test time constraint [10], and obtaining the optimum number of test units [11].

Here, to compare our results with that of Yang and Jin [8], we use the MLE of the mean life of the smallest extreme value distribution, which is the 43rd percentile \$(\hat{t}_{0.43})\$, at design stress.
The readers may refer to [2] [3] [4], [8], [9] for more details.
The example is from [8], which plans accelerated life testing for miniature electromagnetic sealed relays.

The steps under the proposed framework are


1
Preliminary guessed values of parameters are given in [8] as \$\sigma = 0.833, \mu_{d} = 7.55, \mu _{h} = 1.25\$.

In [8], \$\tau_{3} = 25\$ hours (15, 000 cycles), and it was assumed that \$\xi _{2} = {({\xi _{1} + \xi _{3}})}/{2} = \xi _{{\rm 1}}/ 2\$ and \$\pi_{{\rm 2}} = \pi_{3} / 2 = {({1 - \pi _{1}})}/{3}\$; we adopt these values for comparison purpose.

A sensitivity analysis will be carried out later to examine the consequence of misspecification.

2
The vector \${\bf x}\$ of decision variables for the plan are: 

3
Because the cost information about the test is unavailable, for a fair numerical comparison with that of [8], we assume that the targets for the total sample size, and the total test time at three stress levels to be \${\rm T}_{N} =300, {\rm T}_{\rm time} =125\$ hours so that an appropriate cost constraint can be derived.
Setting \$c =1\$ in (3), the optimization model in (6) becomes where, MMNF is set to 10 as in [8].
Preliminary guessed values of parameters are given in [8] as \$\sigma = 0.833, \mu_{d} = 7.55, \mu _{h} = 1.25\$.

In [8], \$\tau_{3} = 25\$ hours (15, 000 cycles), and it was assumed that \$\xi _{2} = {({\xi _{1} + \xi _{3}})}/{2} = \xi _{{\rm 1}}/ 2\$ and \$\pi_{{\rm 2}} = \pi_{3} / 2 = {({1 - \pi _{1}})}/{3}\$; we adopt these values for comparison purpose.

Because the cost information about the test is unavailable, for a fair numerical comparison with that of [8], we assume that the targets for the total sample size, and the total test time at three stress levels to be \${\rm T}_{N} =300, {\rm T}_{\rm time} =125\$ hours so that an appropriate cost constraint can be derived.
Setting \$c =1\$ in (3), the optimization model in (6) becomes where, MMNF is set to 10 as in [8].

We conduct the sensitivity analysis, and compare our results with those of Yang's plan [8], Meeker-Hahn's plans [13], and the best equal expected number failing (BEENF) plans with respect to the following measures considered in [8]:


•
the variance of some specified ML estimator,

•
sensitivity to mis-specifying \$\mu_{d}\$ and \$\mu_{h}\$,

•
total test time (TTT) and sample size needed, and

•
trade-off of the Cost and Svar with different \$\mu_{d}\$ and \$\mu_{h}\$.
We use the same measure (RV) in Yang [8] for comparison purpose.

links.abstract: This paper deals with optimal design of four-level constant-stress accelerated life test plans with various censoring times. The optimum plans choose the stress levels, test units allocated to each stress, and censoring times to minimize the asymptotic variance of the MLE of the mean (log) life at design stress and test length. A FORTRAN-77 program was written to calculate the optimum plan. This paper compares the test plans with existing three-level test plans, and concludes that: the mean numb...

references.title: Planning multiple levels constant stress accelerated life tests

context.text: Our approach is partly motivated by the work of Tang and Yang [12] which revealed that, for multiple levels constant stress ALT, there are many possible test plans which are nearly statistically optimal.

links.abstract: The authors propose a method for planning constant stress accelerated life tests (CSALT) in which the departure from the usual optimality criterion can be quantified. The scheme is illustrated using three stress levels CSALT. In particular, a contour plot is developed to provide the solution space for sample allocation at high stress and the two lower stress levels. Based on the output from the contour plot, three related approaches for planning CSALT are then presented. Finally, a numerical exa...

references.text: L. C. Tang, G. Yang, "Planning multiple levels constant stress accelerated life tests", Proc. Annu. Reliab. Maintain. Symp., pp. 338-342, 2002.
